text: hey thank you very much it's great to be

sector one and every time I come I'm
amazed by the turnout I understand there
were over a thousand registrations today
and I think it's I just find it really
encouraging to see that level of
interest here in Singapore and cloud
technology coming from the public sector
so my name is Sumner lemon I work for
Intel I'm part of our industry Solutions
Group and I lead our team which is
focused on the public sector vertical
and today I want to talk about smart
cities but I want to do it maybe in a
way that you haven't heard it from Intel
before for a company that essentially
makes chips you probably expect us to

when we think about smart cities I think
we've got to really step back and think

do with technology and what the

leaders yeah before working at Intel in
another life I used to be a journalist
and I used to write about technology and
it always used to drive me a little bit
crazy when companies talked about
solutions and when companies do that
they're referring to a bundle of
software and hardware that's designed to
perform a specific function but a
solution really implies that you've got
a problem statement and cities today
certainly have one and here it is so the
obvious is that cities are a primary
engine of economic activity around the
world
they've always played that function
throughout history but cities are
transforming and what you see here is
data from McKinsey looking at the top
600 cities around the world as measured
by GDP contribution looking at 2007
actuals in 2025 forecast and you'll see
a couple of things that might jump out
at you one is that in 2007 these 600
milli 600 cities were home to 485
million households with per capita GDP
of around 20,000 per year by 2025 that
number is going to be 735 million the
per capita GDP of there
$2,000 and within that number 235
million of those households are going to
be in emerging cities and emerging
markets with per capita GDP of $20,000
and what that implies is tremendous
change over a very short period of time
with significant implications for
governments for planners and an
immediate impact on our livelihoods in
the way we live so what you see when you
look around the world now as you're
seeing cities trying to grapple with
this transformation and get ahead of
these changes through the use of
technology and this is where we're
starting to see smart city deployments
coming into being and what you see when
you look around the world in all these
cities that are starting to do this is
they're all focusing on unique
priorities and goals they aren't always
the same you can take a look at San
Diego right San Diego's focus is they
want to save costs they want to reduce

water efficiency in energy efficiency
with smart grids and right here in
Singapore the Singapore government has
articulated a very bold vision for how
it intends to leverage technology to
address the challenges that are facing
Singapore and improve life for all the
citizens and all the people who live
here but what really is smart City when
we talk about smart City what are we
talking about sometimes these terms are
so general they don't really mean
anything but smart city at the highest
level what it implies is secure
management of the resources
infrastructure and services in a city
and within that you're bringing together
disparate data sets from different
sources you're analyzing them to extract
insights that are benefitting city
leaders planners and citizens so from
the city leaders perspective what
they're going to get is they're going to
get insight into how to better advance
their policies how to develop more
effective policies and how to be a
better more responsive government for
the citizens for city planners it's an
opportunity to understand how services
are working and what they need to do
differently
how to improve operational efficiency of
services and scale them more broadly and
for citizens for all of us it's an
opportunity for us to get more
information from our government better
communication it's a chance for greater
civic engagement it's an opportunity for
us to have our voice heard and for them
to be better two-way communication
between citizens and the government now
we think about smart City as a
development vision what it really
requires is bringing together multiple
IT systems and IOT systems and
integrating them into a whole and that
can mean tying together schools
libraries hospitals train systems
airports power stations everything that
goes on the world around us you want to
have integrated because it's through
that integration that you're able to
monitor what's happening and that's
where you start to realize some of the
benefits at smart City can bring so
think about from an economic perspective
the implications for competitiveness and
that's one that's very relevant here in
Singapore a small country has often been
said without any significant natural
resources apart from its people in the
human capital you know how can Singapore
stay ahead and be competitive in the
years to come when you have systems that
enable ease of access to government
services transportation is easy it's
safe you can walk home from the train
station without having to worry about
being mugged or robbed you can get into
the country easily you don't have to
wait in long lines this is the kind of
environment that attracts investment
this is the kind of environment where
top performers want to live this is the
kind of environment that brings country
that brings companies to your country to
invest so real benefit for
competitiveness and think about safety
and security you know for years we've
had CCTV cameras all around us but in
many cases those cameras were just
attached to VCRs and nobody ever saw the
video or did anything with it we're now
at a point where we can analyze that
video in real time and that can mean
police or emergency of service providers
are able to respond to an incident more
quickly but it can also have other
implications you know for example if you
have an elderly person in your home who
may suffer from dementia
and if that person goes out walking and
gets lost doesn't know where they are
you know and you're not able to find
them you know this type of system can
help you quickly identify where that
person is and get them before they get
scared or injured or something bad
happens so real potential benefits for
cities and people alike so when cities
start down this journey and start
thinking about how they can leverage
technology to deliver better service and
to be more effective the advice we
always give them is start with an
inventory of looking at what you have
what are the services that you have
today how effective are they what data
are you getting from those services and
then use that as a starting point to
think about what you need to build out
in the future and what you need to
deliver it you'll have a better
understanding of where your gaps are and
as we've worked with our partners like
AWS we've built out at Intel solutions
in each of these areas the government's
can take and deploy and they can
integrate into their other systems
so think about smart building and energy

it would help us reduce costs it would

say for education it can be about

these are the kinds of opportunities
where city governments can leverage

you know there are a couple of things

just now when I was listening to Brad

unique in the sense that unlike a

right a government exists essentially to

pretty unique and government

and that's because they've been
architected to be reliable and
predictable but at a point in history

and that's going to mean a change in

when city leaders lay out a vision for

to leverage some of the advantages that

services what we tell our customers
maybe it's not the right time to go down

Intel we're in the unique position of

some realist significant technical

it's the compute it's the cloud it's the

Public Safety information you know you

governments and public sector

when they're deploying technology you

because if you take a very vertical eyes
